what: Conserved and Non-conserved Regions from a MSA — conserved_regions
title: Conserved and Non-conserved Regions from a MSA — conserved_regions
text: Returns Conserved Non-conserved Regions MSA.

title: Conserved and Non-conserved Regions from a MSA — conserved_regions
code: conserved_regions(x, ...)  # S4 method for Automorphism conserved_regions(   x,   conserved = TRUE,   output = c("all_pairs", "unique_pairs", "unique") )  # S4 method for AutomorphismList conserved_regions(   x,   conserved = TRUE,   output = c("all_pairs", "unique_pairs", "unique"),   num.cores = multicoreWorkers(),   tasks = 0L,   verbose = FALSE )  # S4 method for AutomorphismByCoef conserved_regions(   x,   conserved = TRUE,   output = c("all_pairs", "unique_pairs", "unique") )  # S4 method for AutomorphismByCoefList conserved_regions(   x,   conserved = TRUE,   output = c("all_pairs", "unique_pairs", "unique") )

title: Conserved and Non-conserved Regions from a MSA — conserved_regions
text: x Automorphism-class, AutomorphismList-class, AutomorphismByCoef AutomorphismByCoefList class object. ... use. conserved Logical, Whether return conserved non-conserved regions. output character string. Type output. num.cores, tasks Integers. Argument num.cores denotes number cores use, .e. many child processes run simultaneously (see bplapply function BiocParallel package). Argument tasks denotes number tasks per job. value must scalar integer >= 0L. documentation job defined single call function, bplapply. task division \(X\) argument chunks. tasks == 0 (default), \(X\) divided evenly possible number workers (see MulticoreParam BiocParallel package). verbose logic(1). TRUE, enable progress bar.

what: Some Physicochemical Properties of DNA bases — dna_phyche
title: Some Physicochemical Properties of DNA bases — dna_phyche
text: data set carries relevant physicochemical properties DNA bases. Available properties : "proton_affinity: " indicatio thermodynamic gradient molecule anionic form molecule upon removal proton (Wikipedia). proton affinity values, given kJ/mol, taken reference (1), also available Wolfram Alpha https://www.wolframalpha.com/ cell phone App 'Wolfram Alpha'.. Reference (2) provides several measurements accomplished several computational experimental approaches. "partition_coef: " 1-octanol/water partition coefficients, logP. physical sciences, partition coefficient (P) distribution coefficient (D) ratio concentrations compound mixture two immiscible solvents equilibrium (3). partition coefficient measures hydrophilic ("water-loving") hydrophobic ("water-fearing") chemical substance . Partition coefficients useful estimating distribution drugs within body. Hydrophobic drugs high octanol-water partition coefficients mainly distributed hydrophobic areas lipid bilayers cells. Conversely, hydrophilic drugs (low octanol/water partition coefficients) found primarily aqueous regions blood serum. partition coefficient values included taken reference (1), also available Wolfram Alpha https://www.wolframalpha.com/  cell phone App 'Wolfram Alpha'. "dipole_moment: " Dipole-dipole, dipole-induced-dipole London force interactions among bases helix large, make free energy helix depend base composition sequence. dipole moment values taken reference (4). dipole moment DNA bases refers measure polarity chemical bonds atoms within nucleobases. Dipole moments arise due differences electronegativity bonded atoms. DNA bases, dipole moments can influence orientation bases interacting molecules surfaces, graphene/h-BN interfaces. concept dipole moments applied analyze electric moments RNA-binding proteins, can help identify DNA-binding proteins provide insights mechanisms prediction. "tautomerization_energy: " term “tautomerism” usually defined structural isomerism low barrier interconversion isomers, example, enol/imino forms cytosine guanine. Tautomerization process chemical structure molecule, DNA bases, undergoes rearrangement atoms. rearrangement results formation different isomers, called tautomers, can exist solution cell. DNA bases can undergo tautomeric shifts, can potentially contribute mutagenic mispairings DNA replication. energy required tautomerization DNA bases known tautomerization energy. values taken reference (2) value base corresponds average values estimated different measurement approaches.

what: DNA base/codon sequence and coordinates represented on a given Abelian group. — get_coord
title: DNA base/codon sequence and coordinates represented on a given Abelian group. — get_coord
text: Given string denoting codon base DNA (RNA) alphabet genetic-code Abelian group given reference (1), function returns object CodonGroup-class carrying DNA base/codon sequence coordinates represented given Abelian group.

title: DNA base/codon sequence and coordinates represented on a given Abelian group. — get_coord
code: get_coord(x, ...)  # S4 method for BaseGroup_OR_CodonGroup get_coord(x, output = c("all", "matrix.list"))  # S4 method for DNAStringSet_OR_NULL get_coord(   x,   output = c("all", "matrix.list"),   base_seq = TRUE,   filepath = NULL,   cube = "ACGT",   group = "Z4",   start = NA,   end = NA,   chr = 1L,   strand = "+" )

title: DNA base/codon sequence and coordinates represented on a given Abelian group. — get_coord
text: x object BaseGroup-class, CodonGroup-class, DNAStringSet DNAMultipleAlignment class carrying DNA pairwise alignment two sequences. Objects BaseGroup-class CodonGroup-class generated functions: base_coord codon_coord, respectively. ... use. output See Value section. base_seq Logical. Whether return base codon coordinates selected Abelian group. codon coordinates requested, number DNA bases given sequences must multiple 3. filepath character vector containing path file fasta format read. argument must given codon & base arguments provided. cube character string denoting one 24 Genetic-code cubes, given references (2 2 3). group character string denoting group representation given base codon shown reference (1). start, end, chr, strand Optional parameters required build GRanges-class. provided default values given function definition used.

title: DNA base/codon sequence and coordinates represented on a given Abelian group. — get_coord
text: object CodonGroup-class class returned output = ''. two slots, first one carrying list matrices second one carrying codon/base sequence information. , x object CodonGroup-class class, list matrices codon coordinate can retrieved x@CoordList information codon sequence x@SeqRanges. output = 'matrix.list', object MatrixList class returned.

title: DNA base/codon sequence and coordinates represented on a given Abelian group. — get_coord
text: Symbols '-' 'N' usually found DNA sequence alignments denote gaps missing/unknown bases represented number: '-1' Z4 '0' Z5. Z64 symbol 'NA' returned codons including symbols '-' 'N'. Although CodonGroup-class object returned functions codon_coord base_coord useful store genomic information, base codon coordinates given numeric magnitudes. Function get_coord provides way get coordinates numeric object object still preserve base/codon sequence information.

title: DNA base/codon sequence and coordinates represented on a given Abelian group. — get_coord
code: ## Load a pairwise alignment data("aln", package = "GenomAutomorphism") aln #> DNAStringSet object of length 2: #>     width seq #> [1]    51 ACCTATGTTGGTATT---GCGCTCCAACTCCTTGGCTCTAGCTCACTACAT #> [2]    51 ATCTATGTTGGTATTACGACGCTCCAATTCCTTGGGTCC------CTCCTT  ## DNA base representation in the Abelian group Z5 coord <- get_coord(     x = aln,     cube = "ACGT",     group = "Z5" ) coord ## A list of vectors #> CodonSeq object of length: 2 #> names(2): coord1 coord2  #> -------  #> Vector of length: 51  #>  [1] 1 2 2 4 1 4 3 4 4 3 3 4 1 4 4 0 0 0 3 2 3 2 4 2 2 1 1 2 4 2 2 4 4 3 3 2 4 2 #> [39] 4 1 3 2 4 2 1 2 4 1 2 1 4 #> ... #> <1 more numeric element(s)> #> Two slots: 'CoordList' & 'SeqRanges' #> -------   ## Extract the coordinate list coordList(coord) #> $coord1 #>  [1] 1 2 2 4 1 4 3 4 4 3 3 4 1 4 4 0 0 0 3 2 3 2 4 2 2 1 1 2 4 2 2 4 4 3 3 2 4 2 #> [39] 4 1 3 2 4 2 1 2 4 1 2 1 4 #>  #> $coord2 #>  [1] 1 4 2 4 1 4 3 4 4 3 3 4 1 4 4 1 2 3 1 2 3 2 4 2 2 1 1 4 4 2 2 4 4 3 3 3 4 2 #> [39] 2 0 0 0 0 0 0 2 4 2 2 4 4 #>   ## Extract the sequence list seqRanges(coord) #> GRanges object with 51 ranges and 2 metadata columns: #>        seqnames    ranges strand |        seq1        seq2 #>           <Rle> <IRanges>  <Rle> | <character> <character> #>    [1]        1         1      + |           A           A #>    [2]        1         2      + |           C           T #>    [3]        1         3      + |           C           C #>    [4]        1         4      + |           T           T #>    [5]        1         5      + |           A           A #>    ...      ...       ...    ... .         ...         ... #>   [47]        1        47      + |           T           T #>   [48]        1        48      + |           A           C #>   [49]        1        49      + |           C           C #>   [50]        1        50      + |           A           T #>   [51]        1        51      + |           T           T #>   ------- #>   seqinfo: 1 sequence from an unspecified genome; no seqlengths  ## DNA codon representation in the Abelian group Z64 coord <- get_coord(     x = aln,     base_seq = FALSE,     cube = "ACGT",     group = "Z64" ) coord #> CodonSeq object of length: 2 #> names(2): coord1 coord2  #> -------  #> Vector of length: 17  #>  [1] 17 15 59 43 51 NA 26 53  4 53 55 41 31 33 28 52  7 #> ... #> <1 more numeric element(s)> #> Two slots: 'CoordList' & 'SeqRanges' #> -------   ## Extract the coordinate list coordList(coord) #> $coord1 #>  [1] 17 15 59 43 51 NA 26 53  4 53 55 41 31 33 28 52  7 #>  #> $coord2 #>  [1] 49 15 59 43 51 18 18 53  4 61 55 42 29 NA NA 53 55 #>   ## Extract the sequence list seqRanges(coord) #> GRanges object with 17 ranges and 2 metadata columns: #>        seqnames    ranges strand |        seq1        seq2 #>           <Rle> <IRanges>  <Rle> | <character> <character> #>    [1]        1         1      + |         ACC         ATC #>    [2]        1         2      + |         TAT         TAT #>    [3]        1         3      + |         GTT         GTT #>    [4]        1         4      + |         GGT         GGT #>    [5]        1         5      + |         ATT         ATT #>    ...      ...       ...    ... .         ...         ... #>   [13]        1        13      + |         TCT         TCC #>   [14]        1        14      + |         AGC         --- #>   [15]        1        15      + |         TCA         --- #>   [16]        1        16      + |         CTA         CTC #>   [17]        1        17      + |         CAT         CTT #>   ------- #>   seqinfo: 1 sequence from an unspecified genome; no seqlengths

what: Get Mutation Score from an AAindex or a Mutation/Distance Matrix — get_mutscore
title: Get Mutation Score from an AAindex or a Mutation/Distance Matrix — get_mutscore
text: function applied get mutation contact potential scores representing similarity/distance amino acids corresponding substitution mutations. scores retrieved mutation matrix statistical protein contact potentials matrix AAindex (ver.9.2). Alternatively, mutation scores can estimated based user mutation matrix, example, see aminoacid_dist codon_dist_matrix.

title: Get Mutation Score from an AAindex or a Mutation/Distance Matrix — get_mutscore
code: get_mutscore(aa1, aa2, ...)  # S4 method for character,character get_mutscore(   aa1,   aa2,   acc = NULL,   aaindex = NULL,   mutmat = NULL,   alphabet = c("AA", "DNA"),   num.cores = 1L,   tasks = 0L,   verbose = FALSE,   ... )  # S4 method for BaseSeq,missing get_mutscore(   aa1,   aa2,   acc = NULL,   aaindex = NULL,   mutmat = NULL,   alphabet = c("AA", "DNA"),   stat = mean,   numcores = 1L,   num.cores = 1L,   tasks = 0L,   output = c("dist", "matrix", "vector"),   na.rm = TRUE,   verbose = TRUE,   ... )  # S4 method for DNAStringSet,missing get_mutscore(   aa1,   aa2,   acc = NULL,   aaindex = NULL,   mutmat = NULL,   alphabet = c("AA", "DNA"),   stat = mean,   num.cores = 1L,   tasks = 0L,   verbose = TRUE,   output = c("dist", "matrix", "vector"),   na.rm = TRUE,   ... )  # S4 method for DNAMultipleAlignment,missing get_mutscore(   aa1,   aa2,   acc = NULL,   aaindex = NULL,   mutmat = NULL,   alphabet = c("AA", "DNA"),   stat = mean,   num.cores = 1L,   tasks = 0L,   verbose = TRUE,   output = c("dist", "matrix", "vector"),   na.rm = TRUE,   ... )

title: Get Mutation Score from an AAindex or a Mutation/Distance Matrix — get_mutscore
text: aa1, aa2 simple character representing amino acids character string letter amino acid alphabet base-triplets DNA/RNA alphabet. aa1 object classes: BaseSeq, DNAStringSet, DNAMultipleAlignment, argument aa2 required. ... use. acc Accession id specified mutation contact potential matrix. aaindex Database requested accession id locate. possible values :  "aaindex2" "aaindex3". mutmat mutation score matrix provided user. alphabet Whether alphabet 20 amino acid (AA) four (DNA)/RNA base alphabet. prevent mistakes, .e., strings "ACG" base-triplet DNA alphabet simply amino acid sequence alanine, cysteine, glutamic acid. num.cores, tasks Parameters parallel computation using package BiocParallel-package: number cores use, .e. many child processes run simultaneously (see bplapply number tasks per job (Linux OS). verbose Optional. num.cores > 1. TRUE, prints function log stdout. stat Statistic used summarize scores DNA sequences provided. aa1 object classes: BaseSeq, DNAStringSet, DNAMultipleAlignment. numcores integer setup number parallel workers via makeCluster. output Optional. Class returned object. aa1 object classes: BaseSeq, DNAStringSet, DNAMultipleAlignment. na.rm logical evaluating TRUE FALSE indicating whether NA values stripped computation proceeds.

title: Get Mutation Score from an AAindex or a Mutation/Distance Matrix — get_mutscore
text: single numeric score numerical vector, aa1 object classes: BaseSeq, DNAStringSet, DNAMultipleAlignment, depending user selection returned object : lower diagonal numerical vector sequence pairwise scores. dist-class object. whole score matrix.

title: Get Mutation Score from an AAindex or a Mutation/Distance Matrix — get_mutscore
text: score matrix provided user, must symmetric matrix 20x20.

title: Get Mutation Score from an AAindex or a Mutation/Distance Matrix — get_mutscore

title: Modular System of Linear Equation Solver (MLE) — modlineq
text: integer vector integers. b integer vector integers. n integer vector integers. .sol Values return equation solvable yield value 0. Default 0.

title: Modular System of Linear Equation Solver (MLE) — modlineq
text: solution exact, numerical vector returned, otherwise, exact solution coordinate, list carrying element diagonal matrix translation vector returned.

title: Modular System of Linear Equation Solver (MLE) — modlineq
text: \(, b\), \(c\) integer scalars, just wrapper function call modlin.

title: Modular System of Linear Equation Solver (MLE) — modlineq
code: ## Set the vector x, y, and m. x <- c(9,32,24,56,60,27,28,5) y <-  c(8,1,0,56,60,0,28,2) modulo <- c(64,125,64,64,64,64,64,64)  ## Try to solve the modular equation a x = b mod n m <- modlineq(a = x, b = y, n = modulo) m #> [1]  8 43  0  1  1  0  1 26  ## Or in matrix form  diag(m) #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [,5] [,6] [,7] [,8] #> [1,]    8    0    0    0    0    0    0    0 #> [2,]    0   43    0    0    0    0    0    0 #> [3,]    0    0    0    0    0    0    0    0 #> [4,]    0    0    0    1    0    0    0    0 #> [5,]    0    0    0    0    1    0    0    0 #> [6,]    0    0    0    0    0    0    0    0 #> [7,]    0    0    0    0    0    0    1    0 #> [8,]    0    0    0    0    0    0    0   26  ## The reverse mapping is an affine transformation mt <- modlineq(a = y, b = x, n = modulo, no.sol = 1L) mt #> $diag #> [1]  1 32  1  1  1  1  1  1 #>  #> $translation #> [1]  1  0 24  0  0 27  0  3 #>   ## That is, vector 'x' is revovered with the transformaiton (y %*% diag(mt$diag) + mt$translation) %% modulo #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [,5] [,6] [,7] [,8] #> [1,]    9   32   24   56   60   27   28    5  # Or cat("\n---- \n") #>  #> ----   (y %*% diag(mt$diag) + mt$translation) %% modulo == x #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [,5] [,6] [,7] [,8] #> [1,] TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE

what: Classification of DNA base mutations — mut_type
title: Classification of DNA base mutations — mut_type
text: DNA/RNA base can classified three main classes according three criteria (1): number hydrogen bonds (strong-weak), chemical type (purine-pyrimidine), chemical groups (amino versus keto). criterion produces partition set bases: 1) According number hydrogen bonds (DNA/RNA double helix): strong \(S=(C,G)\) (three hydrogen bonds) weak \(W=(,U)\) (two hydrogen bonds). According chemical type: purines \(R=(, G)\) pyrimidines \(Y=(C,U)\). 3). According presence amino keto groups base rings: amino \(M=(C,)\) keto \(K=(G,U)\). , mutational event can classified according type involved (2).

title: Amino acid numerical matrix — peptide_phychem_index
text: aa character string, DNAStringSet DNAMultipleAlignment class object carrying DNA pairwise alignment two sequences. ... use. acc Accession id specified mutation contact potential matrix. aaindex Database requested accession id locate aminoacid indices can obtained. possible values : "aaindex2" "aaindex3". userindex User provided aminoacid indices. can numerical vector matrix (20 x 20). numerical matrix provided, aminoacid indices computes column averages. alphabet Whether alphabet 20 aminoacid (AA) four (DNA)/RNA base alphabet. prevent mistakes, .e., strings "ACG" base-triplet DNA alphabet simply amino acid sequence alanine, cysteine, glutamic acid. genetic.code, .init.codon, .fuzzy.codon given function translation. num.cores, tasks Parameters parallel computation using package BiocParallel-package: number cores use, .e. many child processes run simultaneously (see bplapply number tasks per job (Linux OS). verbose TRUE, prints function log stdout.

title: Amino acid numerical matrix — peptide_phychem_index
text: Depending user specifications, mutation contact potential matrix, list available matrices (indices) ids index names can returned. specifically: aa_mutmat: Returns aminoacid mutation matrix statistical protein contact potentials matrix. aa_index: Returns specified aminoacid physicochemical indices.

title: Amino acid numerical matrix — peptide_phychem_index
text: DNA sequence given, assumed DNA base-triplet sequence, .e., base sequence must multiple 3. Errors can originated given sequences carry letter DNA aminoacid alphabet.

title: Amino acid numerical matrix — peptide_phychem_index
text: Robersy Sanchez https://genomaths.com

title: Amino acid numerical matrix — peptide_phychem_index
code: ## Let's create DNAStringSet-class object base <- DNAStringSet(x = c( seq1 ='ACGTCATAAAGT',                             seq2 = 'GTGTAATACAGT',                             seq3 = 'TCCTCATAAGGT'))  ## The stop condon 'TAA' yields NA aa <- peptide_phychem_index(base, acc = "EISD840101") aa #> MatrixSeq with 3 rows (sequences) and 4 columns (aminoacids/codons): #> -------  #>       A1    A2   A3    A4 #> S1 -0.18 -0.26   NA -0.26 #> S2  0.54    NA 0.02 -0.26 #> S3 -0.26 -0.26   NA  0.16 #> -------  #> Slots: 'seqs', 'matrix', 'names', 'aaindex', 'phychem', 'accession  ## Description of the physicochemical index aa@phychem #> [1] "EISD840101 Consensus normalized hydrophobicity scale (Eisenberg, 1984)"  ## Getthe aminoacid sequences. The stop codon 'TAA' is replaced by '*'. aa@seqs #>   seq1   seq2   seq3  #> "TS*S" "V*YS" "SS*G"    aa <- peptide_phychem_index(base, acc = "MIYS850103", aaindex = "aaindex3") aa #> MatrixSeq with 3 rows (sequences) and 4 columns (aminoacids/codons): #> -------  #>         A1     A2      A3     A4 #> S1 -0.0045 0.0015      NA 0.0015 #> S2  0.0895     NA -0.0565 0.0015 #> S3  0.0015 0.0015      NA 0.0220 #> -------  #> Slots: 'seqs', 'matrix', 'names', 'aaindex', 'phychem', 'accession  ## Description of the physicochemical index aa@phychem #> [1] "MIYS850103 Quasichemical energy of interactions in an average buried environment"

code: ## Create a list x <- list(a = 1:10, beta = exp(-3:3), logic = c(TRUE, FALSE, FALSE, TRUE)) class(x) <- "nice"  ## To compute the list mean for each list element using 'base::lapply' class(slapply(x, mean, simplify = FALSE)) #> [1] "list"  ## Simply 'base::lapply' preserving attributes slapply(x, mean, keep.attr = TRUE, simplify = FALSE) #> $a #> [1] 5.5 #>  #> $beta #> [1] 4.535125 #>  #> $logic #> [1] 0.5 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "nice"  ## To preserve attributes and simplify slapply(x, mean, keep.attr = TRUE, simplify = TRUE) #>        a     beta    logic  #> 5.500000 4.535125 0.500000  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "nice"

title: GenomAutomorphism 1.0.2
text: Fix error parallel computation Windows (12/08/2022)

title: GenomAutomorphism 1.0.1
text: Expanding analyses including aminoacid similarity based codon distances. Three new functions added: codon_dist, codon_dist_matrix, aminoacid_dist. See tutorial applying functions https://.gd/oYLDK4.

title: GenomAutomorphism 1.0.0
text: Release Bioconductor (version 3.16). https://doi.org/doi:10.18129/B9.bioc.GenomAutomorphism

title: GenomAutomorphism 0.99.4
text: Expanding analyses including amino acid similarity statistical protein contact potentials matrices Amino Acid Index Database https://www.genome.jp/aaindex/. Improving documentation. Fixed bug introduced change protein coding frameshift.

title: GenomAutomorphism 0.99.3
text: Documentation improvement. Package accepted Bioconductor (07/18/22)

title: GenomAutomorphism 0.99.2

title: GenomAutomorphism 0.99.0
